p: At their most straightforward, DNA barcoding approaches can identify alien species at a given location (Darling and Blum 2007). They are now proving useful for a range of taxa. Mostly, the aim has been to characterize the diversity of an assemblage and identify alien species among its members in a given recipient area, or to verify whether given populations are from species thought to be nonindigenous (e.g. Scheffer et al. 2006; Smith and Fisher 2009; Porco et al. 2012, 2013; Fernández-Álvarez and Machordom 2013; Zhang et al. 2013a). Such approaches nonetheless are subject to the same kinds of problems as those facing DNA barcoding generally (see review by Taylor and Harris 2012). These include substantial error rates in some taxonomic groups (e.g. Hickerson et al. 2006; Meier et al. 2006; Zhang et al. 2013b) and lack of clarity about the questions being posed or rigorous independent assessment of the hypotheses being tested (Collins and Cruickshank 2013).
